thread.title: Rossview, MCHS are still fighting for playoff lives
thread.title_full: Rossview, MCHS are still fighting for playoff lives

title: Rossview, MCHS are still fighting for playoff lives
text:
Rossview, MCHS are still fighting for playoff lives George Robinson, grobinson@theleafchronicle.com 7:08 p.m. CDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo Rossview quarterback Jordan Justice sets to throw the ball against West Creek in a Region 7-5A football game two weeks ago. The Hawks face Centennial Friday night. (Photo: George Robinson/The Leaf-Chronicle) Buy Photo 7 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CLARKSVILLE, Tenn. â€” The fallout from Clarksville High's use of an ineligible football player this season has pushed several teams the Wildcats have beaten back into the playoff picture. 
One of those teams is Rossview. 
The Hawks were beaten by CHS, 42-35, last month and were looking up at the four playoff eligible spots in the Region 7-5A standings. But the forfeiture of five Clarksville wins gave the Hawks an extra victory and now Ex-Clarksville High player's family wants answers 
Rossview finds itself that fourth team in the region standings and currently in the playoff picture. 
Rossview must find a way to maintain that status as the final two games arrive. The first test will be a large one as Rossview plays host to Centennial at 7 p.m. Friday. 
The Cougars are 5-0 in region play and 7-1 overall. They haven't lost since Week 2 when Class 6A power Independence ran over Centennial 49-6. The Cougars have scored more than 40 points in each game in the past month while holding their opponents to under double-digit points during that time span. 
Rossview has won four of its last five games if you include the game against CHS and destroyed West Creek two weeks ago before enjoying a bye week last Friday. Buy Photo 
Montgomery Central's Alec Cowan (15) looks to lead the Indians against Northwest in a Region 6-4A football game Friday night at Northwest High School. (Photo: George Robinson/The Leaf-Chronicle) 
But while the Hawks (6-2, 3-2) look to stay on postseason track, Montgomery Central and Northwest are equally determined to get to the playoffs. The two teams play each other at 7 p.m. at Northwest High School Friday. 
Central also had a much-needed bye week to reassess its season. The Indians were riding high, starting the season on a four-game win streak. But Central has since lost four straight games leaving it hanging on by a thread to that fourth and final playoff spot in the Region 6-4A standings. 
Northwest is tied in the standings with Central at 1-2 and a win against the Indians Friday would flip the two teams' positions in the standings, meaning it would vault the Vikings into the fourth spot while dropping the Indians down. That would set up all kinds of issues for both teams in the final week of the season next Friday. Montgomery Central faces third-place Hillwood next week while Northwest takes on last-place Creek Wood. 
Every coach will say that he's only interested in controlling what his team can control and not looking beyond the game this week. But it's hard not to sneak a peek into the future. 
Reach Prep writer George Robinson at 931-245-0747 and on Twitter @Cville_Sports. 
FRIDAY'S PREP FOOTBALL GAMES 
Time: 7 p.m. 
Records: Northeast (3-5, 1-4 in Reg. 7-5A), West Creek (1-7, 1-4 in Reg. 7-5A) 
Notes: The ineligibilty issue swirling around Clarksville High has put this game in a much more important light for Northeast while giving West Creek its only win of the season. The Coyotes won't be going to playoffs but it has to be comforting knowing the season has at least one win on the schedule. For the Eagles, they need to win out (including beating Rossview next week) to have a shot at the postseason. 
Clarksville Academy vs. Perry County 
Where: Linden, Tenn. 
Time: 7 p.m. 
Records: Clarksville Academy (4-4, 3-2 in Reg. 6-A), Perry County (0-8, 0-5 in Reg. 6-A) 
Notes: The Cougars were hammered by Huntingdon last week but get a chance to take out that frustration on winless Perry County. It's a win the Cougars need and should get. They are currently in the fourth-place spot in the region standings, tied with Houston County and Bruceton. Bruceton plays Houston County Friday, and the Cougars face the Fighting Irish next week in a huge game. If both the Cougars and Irish win Friday, they will have secured a playoff spot and next week's showdown will be moot. 
Houston County vs. Hollow Rock-Bruceton 
Where: Bruceton, Tenn. 
Time: 7 p.m. 
Records: Houston County (6-2, 3-2 in Reg. 6-A), Hollow Rock-Bruceton (5-3, 3-2 in Reg. 6-A). 
Notes: This is a huge game for the Fighting Irish, who come off a thumping of Perry County last week. The Irish need to basically win this game to secure a spot in the Class A playoffs for the first time since 2009. They also need a springboard into next week's rivalry game against Clarksville Academy. 
Creek Wood vs. Kenwood 
Time: 7 p.m. 
Records: Creek Wood (3-5, 0-3 in Reg 6-4A), Kenwood (5-3, 2-1 in Reg. 6-4A) 
Notes : Kenwood is in second place in the region standings and looks secure in the knowledge that it will be going to the playoffs for the fourth straight year. But there isn't much separating the Knights from teams stacked in the middle of the 6-4A standings like Hillwood, Montgomery Central and Northwest. 
Dickson County vs. Clarksville High 
Where: Hilda J. Richardson Field 
Time: 7 p.m. 
Records: Dickson County (2-6, 0-5 in Reg. 7-5A), Clarksville High (1-7, 1-4 in Reg. 7-5A). 
Notes: Clarksville's use of an ineligible player cost the Wildcats five wins, dropping their record to only 1-7 and basically eliminating the team from a playoff appearance it had wrapped up with its win against Northeast two weeks ago. Now CHS plays for pride despite a difficult week of practice for the team. 
Sycamore vs. Stewart County 
Time: 7:30 p.m. 
Records: Stewart County (3-5, 1-3 in Reg. 6-3A), Sycamore (5-4, 3-2 in Reg. 6-3A) 
Notes: As of Friday morning, Stewart County is on the outside, looking in at the playoff race. The Rebels sit in fifth place, one spot from that coveted top four position. To get to the postseason coach Cody Finley's team would need to win out, then get some help, which would be Harpeth losing its final two games. 7 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://leafne.ws/1RZUyHg TOP VIDEOS
